simone

Quite often I come across threads discussing abortion where it is quite evident that the only posters are men. After reading these posts I feel like a piece of real estate with a bunch of strangers walking all over my body and stomping on me and loudly debating my worth and what I might be used for.
 
 Now it appears that there is a new anti-choice tactic:
 
 Women as Environments for the Pweshious Widdo Fetuses
 
 It is quite evident that women are not considered by these anti-choicers as part of the human race, as real human persons, as individuals, as citizens, having rights, liberty and the freedom to pursue happiness as is written in our nation's (the United States) foundation documents.

 I think you're over-complicating the anti-choice position. A majority of anti-choice posts I've read are essentially based on their 2000 year-old mythical belief system, when women were not considered a particularly valuable portion of society for tasks other than child bearing and scullery purposes. Unless, of course, capable of immaculate conception, still unproven, yet enjoying dogmatic status. If you refute those mythical beliefs, regardless of any country's constitution, to those posters you're actually less than a piece of real estate and definitely non-human, male or female.

Should a woman be allowed to have the unborn attached to her as long as she wants? 
OK, one small step accomplished. Now, let's take a look at the construction of your question. What, precisely, do you mean by the phrase "be allowed to have the unborn attached to her"? I keep seeing an unfortunate woman with a fetus attached to her person by super glue or something like that. And, what about the subphrase "be allowed"? Who is doing the allowing?
 
 
Can she have the 'baby' feeding on her bodily resources for life?
I'm having a problem with the phrase "for life." Does this mean for the entire life of the woman? Does it mean that the feeding on bodily resources is to maintain the life of the 'baby'?
Howard Beale

Howard, I know, but somehow I cannot stop trying to bring understanding to these folks.
For people to come to an understanding they both have to be willing to be honest and open. You very seldom see that in this particular forum. Everyone is always jockeying for position. Winning has become more important than understanding. Being Right has become more important than seeking truth. Many think that if they win some verbal game it justifies everything else. That is why you see questions avoided, consequences scoffed at and beliefs ridiculed. All I can say is to try and stay above that. It is difficult and I know that I often fail despite my desire to do so.
 
 All the best.

 If your arguement is that a woMAN should have a choice in whether or not she wants to continue supporting this less of a being (aka human fetus) then shouldn't the choice go both ways. Just like the woMAN can deny the fetus care via an abortion the woMAN should be allowed to supply care for the fetus as long as she wishes to...even if this is beyond 9 months. And I am not talking about outside the womb here!!! If the woMAN has the choice then can she make it so the baby is just supported off of her body for as long as she desires? Maybe we could attach the fetus to her leg or something. If the woMAN has full control over this inferior creature then shouldn't she be allowed to do this? (By allow I mean legally)
 
 Before you even answer, I will say this arguement I present seems...well...crazy. In fact, I would think many feel the same way, however, if one wishes to allow choice then how can one see it any other way? I'll tell you how. Someone will say "well the baby forces itself out and thus becomes a person". I think maybe we should force the baby to stay in there if the woman wishes. Or maybe it really isn't all about the woman. Maybe it really is about when the unborn is enough of a person to override the desires of the woman. If it is the second one then we really aren't talking about imposing "compulsory gestation and forced parturition on women" as suggested by simone and Howard Beale but rather when a human is worthy of life which is the real question.

 Your logic is barely followable sometimes. 
 
 The nine months up until birth of everyone's life a fetus is physically dependent upon the mother. There is no other option. It is 100% the burden of the mother. There are a bunch of valid reasons why this relationship may not work for the mother. I think a lot of those reasons could be addressed if we all got together and tried to help her, but we don't. Instead, a lot of energy is spent refuting really stupid Disneyland gone wrong analagies that work to demonize, trivialize, and undermine the role of the mother and the impacts of pregnancy.
 
 After birth EVERYTHING changes. The attachment to the mother is no longer a physical, biological necesity. Other people besides the mother can take care of the baby.
 
 Quit trying to compare the impacts of pregnancy to caring for a child. THEY AREN'T THE SAME THING. Not even close.
